8/8 My amendment will allow NOAA to improve the efficiency and accuracy of its wildfire detection efforts and will enable communities facing wildfires to be notified more quickly about the size and location of each fire.
7/8 Further, I offered an amendment to the NDAA, which passed unanimously, to establish a Center for Artificial Intelligence at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA).
6/8 -Reforms designed to improve responses for sex-related offenses

5/8 -Provisions to address the childcare shortage for military families and reform programs that support military families with children with special needs.
-Mental healthcare reforms for service-members, family members and retirees.
-3% pay raise for servicemembers.

4/8 -Authorization of $350 million in defense science and technology efforts to invest in emergency technologies and critical research areas including biotechnology, AI, hypersonics, and directed energy.

3/8 -Multiple authorities to train and equip partners, including Afghan, Iraqi, and other forces, in their fights against terrorism.
-Urgently-needed increases to the Army, Navy, and Air Force end-strength.

2/8 This bipartisan bill includes numerous provisions crucial to our military’s readiness and competitive edge over our adversaries while taking care of our servicemembers and their families. Specifically, the NDAA includes:

The glaring disparities between men and women in the workplace are likely to deepen and last for generations if we do not respond to this crisis. We need a recovery plan that supports working women and families, and I have a few ideas. (6/10)

The mass exodus of women from the workforce will hurt our economy. Women are a massive driver of our GDP, and it is essential that women remain in the workforce to offset aging baby boomers, many of whom are retiring early due to the pandemic. (5/10)

Due to the pandemic, the support system that previously made full-time work and childcare possible for women has been upended. As a result, millions of women—particularly in corporate America—are leaving or considering leaving the labor force to compensate. (4/10)

Moreover, lack of support from both government and employers for balancing work and home responsibilities is pushing women out of the workforce. While men have become increasingly involved, women still typically bear the brunt of housework and childcare responsibilities. (3/10)

Since the start of this crisis, 22 percent of all women have left the workforce. There are several reasons for this. First of all, women—especially women of color—are overrepresented in industries that have been hit hardest by COVID-19, like food service and health care. (2/10)

No matter how we look at the data—by race, by sector, by income—it's clear the burden of the pandemic is falling hardest on women. Today, our office released a report detailing how decades of progress could be erased unless we take action. (THREAD)

Masks alone are not a silver bullet, but they help. They save lives. In the long road ahead, I won’t stop fighting to make sure Arizona has a clear strategy to keep people healthy and get our economy back on track. This is the most basic step we can take. We have to act.

This isn’t about politics, it’s about public health. It’s about whether we can trust our state leaders to manage a crisis and listen to experts. It's clear to me the only way to get the governor to do the right thing is to hold his feet to the fire.
I’ve called for a statewide mandate for months now, and so have countless others – doctors, nurses, teachers, epidemiologists. Yet, Arizona remains one of a few holdout states. It’s costing lives.

To be clear: It wouldn’t impact rental assistance that goes to cities or federal help in unemployment insurance, which are different pots of money. It affects the state and local government aid alone.

To incentivize holdout states, counties, and cities let’s send a message: If you want federal relief funds, mandate masks. That’s good news for most of Arizona counties and cities, which would still get funds and split what the Ducey Administration would otherwise receive.

More than 12,000 new COVID-19 cases in Arizona today. Nearly 7,000 Arizonans have died. Every alarm bell is sounding, yet the governor still refuses to adopt the most basic public health policy measure to keep people safe: a mask mandate.

@ClassCrowder To be clear, this waiver was a new law that was proposed to prevent the application of existing law to one person. There was no provision in existing law to provide for its waiver under certain conditions. The so-called “waiver” legislation was wrong then, and it’s wrong now.

Even before any potential impact from coronavirus, marriage rates hit an all-time low in the United States. Read more: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=672F430A-8F6B-4E77-ABBF-009B041CFE17

Still, when respondents were specifically asked whether “getting married is more important to me than having a successful career,” only 19% agreed. 
https://jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=733E5D3C-2FCD-4C23-B542-1C0213A8BDED

Marriage used to be a part of the path to achieving a stable life, today marriage is viewed as something that should happen only after people have established their careers and are financially secure. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EovQJlpXIAMOBa4.png

This is not too surprising, considering nearly 40% of children in the United States are born outside of marriage.
Could it be that marriage has come to be seen as a “capstone” of adulthood, rather than a “cornerstone” as it used to be? http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EovQGcbXcAA_4v7.png
And while Americans overall seem to think that childbearing should take place within marriage, marriage does not seem to be as important a prerequisite to becoming a parent as are other factors.
However, recent studies show that marriage and parenting fall low on the list of what respondents considered essential to a fulfilling life.
Although family life in America has become less stable over the last several decades, the majority of the American population still agrees that marriage provides value to individuals and society.

Because that's what fiscally responsible people do.  Just don't frame that as a trade off against fiscal responsibility.  An idea for legislation in the 117th, perhaps... /fin

So should we invest in clean energy infrastructure that lowers energy costs, saves money on health expense and helps grow our economy.  Absolutely!  On purely fiscal grounds, as long as the increase in GDP exceeds our borrowing costs.

It also means we over-value the privatization of government assets, since selling off government property is treated as a source of cash flow, but not as an asset value write down.  (See: below market sales of oil & gas leases.)

It means we under-invest in assets, since cash outlays for assets are treated no differently than cash outlays for on-going expense.  (In accounting parlance, we fail to differentiate between capital- and operating expenses.)

That's not to say we should be fiscally irresponsible of course; rather that our failure to create and maintain a federal balance sheet massively distorts the way we think and talk about fiscal policy.
For anyone who says "households balance their budgets, government should too", show me a household that never borrowed money (aka, "deficit spending") to buy a home
For anyone who says "we should run government like a business", show me a business that doesn't have a balance sheet.
This is a real problem: when we "score" bills to evaluate their fiscal impact, we consider impacts on short-term cash flow, but ignore any offsetting increase in asset values.

I'm glad to see this, but wish that discussions of fiscal matters in Washington didn't always confuse the terms "accretive capital investment" and "deficit spending".  https://www.eenews.net/stories/1063720017
